clinical_study.brief_title: Comparing Weaning of Nasal Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) From Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Control Trial of Weaning NCPAP From Preterm Infants: Sudden Wean Versus Weaning by Gradually Decreasing Pressure

brief_summary.textblock: To compare the 2 methods of weaning of nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in premature babies born between 26 and 32 weeks

detailed_description.textblock:
To study the weight and the post menstrual age (PMA) at the time of NCPAP wean utilizing the method of sudden wean as compared to gradual wean.
Methods: A prospective randomized trial was conducted comparing sudden weaning with gradual weaning from NCPAP in neonates with gestational age between 26 and 32 weeks. The patients were randomized to one of the two methods of weaning from NCPAP and their success was compared

primary_outcome.measure: Success of weaning on first trial off NCPAP
primary_outcome.time_frame: Completion of Nasal Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (NCPAP) treatment, expected average of 4 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Weight and corrected GA when come off oxygen
secondary_outcome.time_frame: when off supplemental oxygen expected average of 2 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Weight and corrected gestational age (GA) when neonates could come off NCPAP
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Completion of Nasal Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (NCPAP) treatment, expected average of 4 weeks

other_outcome.measure: length of stay in the neonatal intensive care unit
other_outcome.time_frame: when ready to be discharged, expected average of 6-8 weeks

arm_group.description: When ready Nasal Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (NCPAP) will be removed from the neonate
NCPAP will be removed by gradually decreasing pressure over 24 hours once the weaning is decided

intervention.description: NCPAP will be removed by gradually decreasing pressure over 24 hours once the weaning is decided

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All neonates born 26 to 32 weeks of gestational age
Exclusion Criteria:
- Those with severe congenital anomalies and chromosomal defects including congenital heart disease, neurological malformations, chest and airway abnormalities and lung hypoplasia
